body: This is a great Leatherman, I've used it almost every day since getting it.  While limited in overall tool options, what it has is exactly what most of us need for day-to-day uses.  It's not perfect, but for doing what it does so well, it's also pretty hard to fault.  One thing to note is that this is not very heavy-duty at all.  It flexes easily, and I can see how some folks have broken the pliers trying to use it for more than it can handle.  Still, used within its limitations for light-duty everyday tasks it is fantastic, and is now my EDC.  As an EDC it is a tad heavier and bulkier than a good pocket knife, but not that bad, and the pocket clip does its job.  Considering how much more you can do with it compared to just having a knife, I'd say the trade-off is absolutely worth-it!The Pros:  It is really cool looking, well designed and relatively lightweight.  The 154CM blade is the real deal, though I wish it were just a tad bigger.  There's certainly room to make it so, but as a handy pocket knife the size is fine, and it is razor sharp.  One-handed opening and closing of the blade is extremely easy, and it's very comfortable to use.  The bit drivers are excellent, and the handle folds out to make for a very comfortable full-size feeling screwdriver.  The pliers are great also, as is the wire cutter.  Again, the handle folds out into a very ergonomic design, with a curved bottom piece to wrap your fingers around.As to the Cons:  As mentioned earlier, this is a relatively light-duty tool.  The frame will flex with even a little bit of extra torque to the drivers or pliers.  Excessive force may likely lead to a bent frame or a broken plier jaw.  Used within reason, however, this shouldn't be an issue.  Also, my blade came loose rather quickly; nothing dangerous, but the torx screw needed tightening after a couple weeks of use.  Another valid complaint many have is that the pliers aren't needle-nosed, they are fairly blunt and stubby. Workfine for what they are, but much like with the blade, there's (literally) room for improvement in the design.  Finally, while it's nice to have the carabiner clip and integrated bottle-opener, these are rather superfluous extras in my opinion.  The carabiner clip is rather large and makes the overall size and shape a bit longer and clunkier than it really needs to be on that end.  And the open area inside the carabiner is pretty small, which can make it difficult to clip onto things.  I'd rather see them ditch the carabiner and improve both the size and functionality of the pocket clip, making it both wider and reversible (for tip-up carry).All in all, for EDC the Skeletool CX is hard to beat.  You get a legit one-handed knife blade, an excellent bit driver set and the ubiquitous pliers & wire cutter for just a little more size and weight than a good pocket knife alone.  On top of that it looks really cool, and the frame is very well designed ergonomically, making every tool comfortable in the hand to use.  I highly recommend this for anyone who likes pocket knives, but wants something with even more capabilities for EDC.

title: My favorite multitool so far
body: I've carried this with me almost every day for 4 years. Wouldn't leave home without it. I find that I use all of the tools frequently, I've had swiss army knives in the past and there were some tools I would never use and it felt like wasted space. Pliers, wire cutter, phillips/screw, knife are really all I need to do just about everything. The clips have also been really helpful in keeping it on me without having to worry. If it ever needs replacing I will not hesitate.

title: perfect for a light EDC...
body: I think most negative reviews are from misplaced expectations. This is meant as a lightweight and compact item you can clip in your pocket like a folder(knife). It does this very well. If I needed something for heavy work(or for a B.O.B.)I'd go with the Charge tti. For a casual EDC (every day carry) that you won't even notice until it's needed, this is an excellent tool.

title: Mediocre multi-tool
body: I read all the reviews and had a few concerns about the item.  Top of this list were durability, daily functionality and cost value.  Furthermore, I've been carrying the CRKT ZillaTool, and the CX has some big shoes to fill.Based on some of the lower rated reviews, I tested the CX right out of the box for the hinge breaking.  It stood up to sufficient pressure, but one characteristic of being lightweight is that it is, well, lightweight.  As a daily carry for me, this tool needs to be fairly tough, and I don't think it is, I might suggest one of the less expensive/more durable tools, like the 830846 (I haven't tested this one myself).  The pocket clip caught on something and bent one of the first times I wore it, and it's a pain to take the clip off and straighten out.  Also be careful of the pinch area between the pliers, almost got my thumb caught in there.One reviewer stated they had to wear gloves to use it, but mine wasn't that sharp.  Maybe they just used too much hand lotion. I did agree with another reviewer who noted the difficult angle/position of the handle when using the bit driver.  This will work in a pinch, but don't expect to use much torque.  The tool has a great design, looks awesome, performance leaves me wanting my CRKT (which is about one-third the price).  [[ASIN:B000ZS9ZBC Columbia River Knife And Tool 9060K Zilla Multitool with Black On Black Scales]]

title: One of my most treasured Items.
body: I bought mine over 4 years ago. I love it. I may lose my phone or my wallet, but I have never lost this. I carry it in my front pocket with the clip attached on the outside. I feel I was lucky because back then the 154CM blade came with serrations. I use it everyday. The pliers are sturdy unless you want to twist them sideways. but turning to loosen bolts works great. You should get a pair of pliers for twisting. I have used them for soldering, computer repair, lawnmowers, light car repair and you can open them with one hand, no problem. The knife blade may be 4 years old but it isn't wore down at all from sharpening. (I carry this little knife sharpener and it is great for a quick sharpening, even the serrations. ) [[ASIN:B000O8OTNC Smith's PP1 Pocket Pal Multifunction Sharpener]])  As for losing the extra bits, just remove the bit and tap the part that holds the bit, to tighten the space that holds the bit in place.  The screwdriver works perfectly even though it's a little offset, but without it you can't remove a screw. So, great to have a screwdriver. I purchased the bitpack and it has all sorts of bits included but I rarely use those. If you break something they have a 25year guarantee and everyone says that the service is excellent even though I've never had to use it. It has no scissors, but it will shave paper or hair. :)  In conclusion: this is the best knife/mult-tool I have ever owned! Well worth the price.  No more bulky multi-tools for me.  UPDATE: Last week I broke the pliers, (do not twist). Within 10 days I have a brand new Skeletool after sending them in for warranty service. Cost me $4 shipping. I even said how much I liked the serrated blade and they sent me the same Skeletool with the serrated blade! Awesome customer service!!

title: i don't see the need in carrying a ton of stuff like the wave
body: unbeatable for everyday use... i have nail clippers at home when I need them. i don't see the need in carrying a ton of stuff like the wave. this thing is light weight and the blade is amazing.

title: Plus it looks really cool! Oh
body: I'm not going to write a really long review about this knife. If you are looking at this, you are already probably familiar with the high quality of Leatherman. I was looking for a more day to day knife to leave in my car. The truth is I don't use a lot of the extra tools on many of their other knives. (file, saw etc...) For me, this has most of what I need if I'm out day to day. If I'm doing something that I need that other stuff, shame on me for not bringing my toolbox. In other words it's a very practical knife with out all of the bells and whistle which most of the time I don't use. Plus it looks really cool! Oh, one other thing, I love that you can open the knife with one hand without having to open the whole tool up like other Leatherman multitools.

title: Only one flaw.
body: This tool works great, but it has one flaw. The extra screw driver bit that is not attached eventually fell out and was lost. I knew it would happen when I saw how it was attached, and it eventually did.

title: Skeletool CX review
body: I really like this product. However, I have noticed some slight rusting of the plier part of the product. I generally clean this product after use, but haven't tried applying mineral oil to that area yet to see if this solves the problem. The knife is incredibly sharp and I have been real happy with the purchase of this product so far and would recommend it to anyone on the fence about purchasing this item.

title: Best multitool on the market
body: This is easily the best multitool on the market. I've used mine for over a year and purchased a 2nd one for my toolkit.  This tool sees everyday use at home AND at work.  Aside from some ocasional knife sharpening it hasn't required any maintenance. The smaller of the screw driver is small enough to be used on tiny computer screws while the larger #2 driver works for everything else.  The pliers are notched so larger cables can be stripped as well as cut.       The leatherman guarantee is excellent as well.  I have a non CX skeletool that broke last year.  Leatherman fixed it for the cost of shipping only.  Excellent tool.  Excellent manufacturer

title: Nice lightweight knife with several features
body: I researched the different Leatherman multipurpose knives/tools and decided that this one fills the void of a lightweight knife that is easy to carry.  I have several other Leatherman Multitools but one does not have locking blades and I often nick myself and one of them has everything on it and weighs a lot.  This second one is a great tool but it stays in the tool box and not in my pocket because of the weight.  It is light and as several other reviewer have stated for awhile it seems very stiff to open.I like knives that do not rust.  I have an Old Timer that is a great knife and has steel blades that stay sharp for a long time but the blades got pitted over time.  Most stainless steel blades seem to have to be sharpened after every use.  But I like the idea of the CX with the Tungsten DLC scratch-resistant coating.  Hopefully the blade will stay sharp longer than the usual stainless blade.

title: I find it useful around the house
body: Its is as advertise.  I find it useful around the house.

title: Gets the basic stuff right
body: I've had this for a few months now, and I am very happy with my purchase    It may not have the most 'features', but it does the basics very well. The blade seems to be very good quality, and holds it's edge well. I was a bit concerned about the driver bits, thinking that they would quickly fall out and get lost, but there is a small notch and a spring loaded lever that holds them securely in place.     Unlike some cheaper multi tools I've had, the wire cutters/stripper actually work well, and the caribiner/bottle opener is handy for securing the knife inside a bag or pocket.

title: Dangerous Safety Catch
body: My life has me needing a few basic tools frequently, and the Skeletool is a much better blend of utility than my old Wave, which was too bulky and heavy to have on me all the time. As many have mentioned before, the pocket clip is a godsend. When I was looking over the Skeletool upon receiving it, I noticed the knife has a nubby little raised bump on the face of the safety lock. This little metal bump (which is not a manufacturing flaw - it is on all of them and is supposed to prevent the blade from coming open accidentally) catches the knife at a 90 degree angle (if you consider the knife to be at 0 degrees when closed and 180 when open) while retracting blade. At first I thought this was just mildly annoying since it forces you to push down the safety lock again after you've already disengaged the perfectly adequate safety lock, but decided that this redundancy was possibly designed to make the knife safer.However, a few weeks after I got it, I was using the knife to cut some cloth and when I went to close the knife, it caught on the rounded bump for a moment and then jumped off it. The serrated edge (which, like the rest of the knife, is really quite impressively sharp), propelled by the (reasonable, I assure you) force of me closing the knife, slid under my thumbnail and cut quite deeply into my thumb before I could move my thumb out of the way. I am not a careless person with knives, and I respect the danger that is intrinsic with using them. Every knife I have ever owned (and I've had my fair share) has had a smooth action in closing after unlocking the blade, and the unnatural interruption of that action seems to be a dangerous aberration in this knife's design. It seems to me that the most dangerous part of unlocking the knife is the part where you have to have your thumb sticking in airspace where the blade will be passing momentarily while applying pressure to the backside of the blade. I fail to see the improvement in safety with the secondary catch that has to be operated with the blade 50% closer to your thumb than the first time you unlocked the blade. I wrote Leatherman about this, and a customer service rep I got told me she saw what I was talking about, and although she said that they had no plans for redesign of that feature, she forwarded it to their marketing department anyways. I have no idea what the marketing department could do about this besides maybe photograph it in a way that makes the bump less noticeable, but I let it go.I ended up taking a Dremel to the bump and grinding it off. Since then, I've found it much more safe to use.EDIT: Someone in the comments suggested that I might have a defective or older model as they *should* have a ramp on the blade to push the bump down without you having to interfere with it. This is not the case with mine, but if any other owners of it can weigh in on how this particular feature is designed on their tool, I'd be interested in hearing what the consensus is.  When I wrote Leatherman about it a while ago, they did not mention that it should work otherwise than I described, which is strange. Thoughts?EDIT 2: There are now pictures available of both what the blade should look like and what mine looks like in the pictures section. There is clearly something wrong with mine, although it does not look like a manufacturing defect, merely a design oversight. If I work up the enthusiasm to do so, I'll try to get in touch with Leatherman again and see what the deal is with my blade. Despite buying my Skeletool after the poster (Michael Jackson) who put up pictures of what the blade should look like (with a ramp to depress the safety catch bump) bought his, I may have received an older model. Either that or Leatherman has begun cutting corners to save money (or NOT cutting corners in this case). I'm sorry it seems nobody is finding this review helpful. I don't think I'm being UNhelpful by mentioning defects in this product,but maybe those of you who have marked this review as not being helpful would like to weigh in?marked this review as not being helpful would like to weigh in?

title: Got it for all members of my family in Ukraine ...
body: Got it for all members of my family in Ukraine. It's really light, decent. When something happened, you simply need basic, quality tool in your hand - to take out the nail or piece of glass. You won't be able to do it with your bare hands. Again, agree, a little bit expensive, but when time will come - you never regret on the right materials and quality.

title: Best EDC utility for the field
body: Best EDC utility for the field. I used to carry the wave in a pouch, This is much more sleek and lightweight, I love that it has a clip and the blade is still easy to deploy. Very functional for my trade.

title: Five Stars
body: Excellent

title: Five Stars
body: Good

title: It's perfect for daily carry
body: It has all the function without the weight of larger multitools. It's perfect for daily carry.

title: Four Stars
body: good!!

title: Awesome
body: I bought one for me and one for my husband. He always has his in his pocket, and it really is that versatile and useful. I even checked a bag at the airport for the $25 fee because my husband forgot to put this in his luggage. Totally worth it. I keep mine hanging next to my work table and I use it everyday for one reason or another.

title: I don't normally review items, but...
body: I must review this little gadget!    Let me tell you that the minute you hold this little multitool in your hand, you will be completely blown away by its quality and the craftsmanship that went into making it. There's really no more to be said here. It is exactly as pictured, and then some!    I don't understand how anybody can rate this useful tool with anything but 5 stars. Several people criticized this piece for being moderately heavy for its size. While I agree that it is no feather, I also believe that the actual weight precisely matches its heavy-duty-like design and appearance. And let's face it, it's a relatively cheap multitool made almost entirely from Stainless Steel. If you wanted this same configuration in super light weight, it would have to be made from something like titanium, which in turn means that it would have to retail at $200+.    The only thing I found strange is that the tool is a little greasy in certain places. I'm not sure if anybody else noticed this. I suppose this is intentional and helps lubricate the swivels. Note that this is not a complaint, but a mere observation.

title: love it
body: best they make, hands down

title: Fantastic
body: Great quality item. The clip works great as it can easily attach to a belt loop on your pants. I never leave home without it since I received it. Great tool to have.

title: great product
body: I bought them as a gift. They are well made a come with a warrenty father loves them. The knife blade had a small chip in it then opened but does not hurt the knife.

title: If you don't have one, buy one
body: An excellent tool for an excellent price. Well constructed and the size of a mid-size EDC pocket knife. Mine does not leave my side.

title: Amazing
body: I used it much more than I anticipated.. Until I lost it. I'll most likely buy another in the near future. Most multitools are really uncomfortable after some use, this one is great. I also liked the easily accessible knife.

title: great product
body: Received the product very fast and in perfect shape.  The item is as described and has completely met and exceeded my expectations.  I would definitely order this again and I'm glad I read all the reviews first.  In response to the Negative reviews below, I have not found them to be accurate.  This is the best leatherman out there.

title: Happy with the Skeletool CX Mulitool
body: The Leatherman 830850 Skeletool CX Multitool was purchased as a Christmas gift and it was exactly like what I ordered. The look with the black handles gives it a sharper allure. Haven't had time to see if it holds up strong for him, but it has all he wanted and I was satisfied with the shipping and the box was in good shape when it arrived.
